conclusion: The wire ab has a length L and carries a current I. The magnetic field B is directed into the paper. The spring scales read F1.
The magnetic force on a current-carrying conductor in a magnetic field is given by F_m = B I L.

premise: The current flows from a to b, and the magnetic field is into the paper.
conclusion: The magnetic force will be directed out of the paper according to the right-hand rule.

premise: The magnetic force is directed out of the paper.
conclusion: This force adds to the weight of the wire, so the tension in each spring scale is T = mg + B I L.
F1 = T = mg + B I L.
The current is reversed and its magnitude becomes 2I.
The direction of the magnetic force changes to into the paper.

premise: The current is 2I and the magnetic field is B.
conclusion: The new magnetic force is F_m' = 2B I L.

premise: The magnetic force is into the paper.
conclusion: This force subtracts from the weight of the wire, so the tension in each spring scale is now T' = mg - 2B I L.

premise: Equations: F1 = mg + B I L and F2 = mg - 2B I L.
conclusion: Subtract the second equation from the first: F1 - F2 = 3B I L.
Solve for B: B = (F1 - F2) / (3 I L).
